newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai T-bill repo rates end down, spots up.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai T-bill repo rates end down, spots up.

text.p: Contracts on the treasury bill repurchase market in Shanghai closed mostly down on Tuesday on a technical correction after solid gains in the past few days on the back of the surging domestic A share markets, traders said.
The annual rate for the most actively traded seven-day contract fell to 9.51 percent from 11.20 percent on Monday.
Total turnover of the six-contract market tumbled to 5.7 million lots from 11.3 million.
One lot is 1,000 yuan face value of treasury bills.
Traders said that after the surges of the past few trading days, a technical correction on Tuesday had been expected.
In addition, there were no new A share issues on the stock markets today, limiting the demand for funds, they said.
"Today's fall in the repo rates was mainly due to a technical correction," said one trade. "The lack of any new A share issues also decreased fund demand."

Trading volume dropped sharply today due to a sense that the A share indices were now high after the bull run of recent months, deterring speculators from borrowing heavily on the repo market to trade on the stock markets, traders said.
But traders said they expected the contracts to rise slightly in the next few days due to a number of new A share issues.
"The higher yields of existing contracts attracted a lot of buying today," one trader said.
But traders said the combined spot market volume was still thin today, indicating that there would be no solid gains for existing contracts in the short term.
They said the performance of domestic A share markets in the next few days would be the key factor affecting the spot market.
If the A markets continued their bull run, the spot market would fall with liquidity flowing out, they said.
